titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Grants E-G FA732C FA732C

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2016-07-13 20:48:26 -0400.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details.
Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note
phystech.p: Materials requiring specialized equipment for access (film, audio, video, slides) may be restricted from scholarly research dependent on availability of the applicable equipment.
Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be restricted from scholarly research at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services/RAC Head of Reference.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Files for Ford Foundation grants made to institutions/organizations that have been closed/inactive for 10 years or more are open for scholarly research. In addition, there is a selection of 8 Grant Files which remain restricted from scholarly access.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Each Ford Foundation Grant and the corresponding Grant File is identified by a unique Program Action (PA) number. PA numbers begin with the year a grant was made (2-digits), followed by a sequential number within that year (4-digits).

For example: PA 55-0123 was the 123rd grant made in the year 1955. PA numbers are often typed or handwritten on Ford documents in the following format: 55-123 (year)-(####). However, the Ford Foundation’s grants database (LINKS) uses an 8-digit format for PA numbers: 05500123 (0YY#####).
Beginning in the 1970s the 4th digit in the 8-digit PA number was used to encode at least three different types of Ford grants:

list.item: 0YY5#### = Delegated Authority Grants (DAG) / Delegated Authority Projects (DAP)

arrangement.p: After the year 2000 a “1” is used as the first digit in the 8-digit PA number to signify the 21st century. For example the 123rd grant made in 2012 would be PA number 11200123.
Grant Files were not microfilmed in numerical order, and the Ford Foundation’s LINKS database must be used to identify on which microfilm reel (or reels) any specific Grant File is housed.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: Grant Files are indexed in the Ford Foundation’s grants database (LINKS). This database is not available to the public. The Ford Foundation Central Index cards, 1950-1996 (FA736) also provide indexing for Grant Files, and can be searched by institutional/organizational name, personal name, grant location, and subject. Grant Files from 1953 to 1974 are also listed by PA number in the Fund File Index.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Each Ford Foundation Grant File is arranged into 4 sections:

Section 1. BASIC DOCUMENTS: Program Action Forms Accepted Proposals Tax Forms an d Certifications Docket Excerpts Request for Grant Action (RGA) Grant Notification Letter & Budget Terms of Grant Grant Acceptance Letter Supplementary Requests & Agreements Modification Requests & Agreements Section 2. PAYMENTS: Requests Letters Acknowledgments Section 3. REPORTS: Grant Status Report Forms Grantee Narrative and Financial Reports Section 4. CORRESPONDENCE: All other correspondence and material, in reverse chronological order

A possible 5th section, ‘ATTACHMENTS’, will contain copies of printed ephemera & clippings related to the grant. Grant Files may also be followed by a ‘Grants Accounting File’ which summarizes the grant.

Also, early Grant Files (roughly 1950-1970) often include a CROSS REFERENCE sheet listing other grants made in a related subject or Program Area, and a ‘BIBLIOGRAPHY of GRANT-RELATED MATERIALS’ at the beginning of the file.

otherfindaid.p: For descriptions of Ford Foundation Grants, please refer to the following findng aids (arranged alphabetically):

Kalem (attend theaters in England and Europe); Stanley Kauffman (visit film directors, producers, writers, and actors in Europe); Jules Langsner (travel project for a critic of art and architecture); Esther McCoy (survey of architects under the age of thirty-five in the United States); Eric Salzman (visit major new music centers in Europe); Franz Schulze, (travel and writing); Jerry Tallmer, (visit European theaters); Wolfe Von Eckardt (critical report on current urban design in major American cities, and comparisons to contemporary urban projects in Europe); and Peter B. Yates (travel the U.S. to discover and meet with creative meet creative artists).

1964 Grantees include: Jean R. Allan (travel and study of American art); Renee R. Hall (visit professional and educational dance centers in the U.S.); Ann H. Holmes (observe resident and repertory theaters in the U.S.); Edward T. Kelly (study of contemporary art in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe); Robert C. Marsh (study of contemporary American opera); Richard O. Martin (study of ballet); Mary Fuller McChesney (audio tape interviews with artists, and book); Julius Novick (study of theater); Gordon M. Rogoff (study of resident theater companies); Jean M. White (development of a program for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts); and Clair Wolfe (study Dada concept and contemporary developments in Pop Art and New Realism).

scopecontent.head: Program Name
scopecontent.p: Office Of The Arts;Office Of Vice President -Finance & Administration

fileplan.head: Former file ID
fileplan.p: E-12: Program for Critics, Reviewers, and Editors in the Performing and Visual Arts.
